BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and wet snow represent the main danger. The avalanche danger will increase during the day.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind, wind slabs formed in the last few days in high Alpine regions. These can be released, even by a single winter sport participant and reach medium size.
As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation moist snow slides and avalanches are possible as the day progresses. Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large natural avalanches are possible in particular on steep sunny slopes.
Low altitudes: On very steep grassy slopes these can slide on the ground.
Off-piste activities call for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
30 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last three days above approximately 2000 m. Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be quite good over a wide area. The spring-like weather conditions will give rise to increasing settling of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes. Above approximately 2000 m there is still a very large amount of snow.
In the last few days numerous small and medium-sized avalanches were reported.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather conditions will give rise to increasing consolidation of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and wet snow represent the main danger. The avalanche danger will increase during the day.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind, wind slabs formed in the last few days in high Alpine regions. These can be released, even by a single winter sport participant and reach medium size.
As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation moist snow slides and avalanches are possible as the day progresses. Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large natural avalanches are possible in particular on steep sunny slopes.
Low altitudes: On very steep grassy slopes these can slide on the ground.
Off-piste activities call for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
30 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last three days above approximately 2000 m. Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be quite good over a wide area. The spring-like weather conditions will give rise to increasing settling of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes. Above approximately 2000 m there is still a very large amount of snow.
In the last few days numerous small and medium-sized avalanches were reported.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather conditions will give rise to increasing consolidation of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Significant warming: The danger of wet avalanches will increase during the day.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of warming and solar radiation, the natural activity of wet avalanches will rapidly increase. This applies on steep east and west facing slopes below approximately 2800 m, as well as on steep south facing slopes in all altitude zones. This also applies on shady slopes below approximately 2600 m. The wet avalanches can release the saturated snowpack and reach large size in isolated cases. In steep gullies avalanches can in isolated cases reach as far as the valley bottom.
The mostly small wind slabs of the last few days can be released in isolated cases on steep shady slopes at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.

On steep grassy slopes more frequent medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large gliding avalanches are possible below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

Backcountry tours and ascents to alpine cabins should be started and concluded very early.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The weather will be very warm. The surface of the snowpack will freeze to form a strong crust and will already soften in the late morning. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise from early morning to increasing and thorough wetting of the snowpack. These conditions will cause a substantial weakening of the snowpack. In areas with a thinner snowpack the saturation and consequently the loss of strength happens more rapidly
Hardly any snow is lying at low and intermediate altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be exceptionally warm. The summery weather conditions will give rise to rapid and thorough wetting of the snowpack at elevated altitudes. The danger of wet and gliding avalanches will increase quickly during the day.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Significant warming: The danger of wet avalanches will increase during the day.

As a consequence of warming and solar radiation, the natural activity of wet avalanches will rapidly increase. BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of warming and solar radiation, the natural activity of wet avalanches will rapidly increase. This applies on steep east and west facing slopes below approximately 2800 m, as well as on steep south facing slopes in all altitude zones. This also applies on shady slopes below approximately 2600 m. The wet avalanches can release the saturated snowpack and reach large size in isolated cases. In steep gullies avalanches can in isolated cases reach as far as the valley bottom.
The mostly small wind slabs of the last few days can be released in isolated cases on steep shady slopes at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.

On steep grassy slopes more frequent medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large gliding avalanches are possible below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

Backcountry tours and ascents to alpine cabins should be started and concluded very early.

The weather will be very warm. The surface of the snowpack will freeze to form a strong crust and will already soften in the late morning. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise from early morning to increasing and thorough wetting of the snowpack. These conditions will cause a substantial weakening of the snowpack. In areas with a thinner snowpack the saturation and consequently the loss of strength happens more rapidly
Hardly any snow is lying at low and intermediate altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be exceptionally warm. The summery weather conditions will give rise to rapid and thorough wetting of the snowpack at elevated altitudes. The danger of wet and gliding avalanches will increase quickly during the day.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and wet snow require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The clearly visible wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence in all aspects at high altitude. In addition from the late morning in all aspects, an increasing number of medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large wet avalanches are possible. This applies in particular on very steep slopes above approximately 2000 m, as well as at the base of rock walls. In particular on shady slopes the avalanches can penetrate even deep layers. Backcountry tourers or freeriders can release avalanches easily.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The surface of the snowpack will soften during the day. As a consequence of warming during the day the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent as the day progresses. The new snow of Wednesday must be evaluated with care and prudence in all aspects above approximately 2700 m. Towards its surface, the snowpack is moist and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is barely capable of bearing a load. The surface of the snowpack will freeze to form a strong crust only at high altitudes and will soften during the day.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The sometimes large wind slabs of the last few days can still be released in some cases in particular on wind-protected shady slopes above approximately 2800 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be quite good. As the day progresses as a consequence of warming during the day there will be an increase in the danger of moist and wet avalanches. Below approximately 2800 m medium-sized to large wet loose snow avalanches are possible. In particular in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain sometimes large wind slabs formed.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Towards its surface, the snowpack is moist and its surface has a strong crust. As the day progresses as a consequence of warming during the day there will be an increase in the danger of moist and wet avalanches. In particular adjacent to ridgelines as well as at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Early morning: Slab avalanches are possible adjacent to ridgelines. In particular, however, as the day progresses small and medium-sized moist snow slides and avalanches are to be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind slabs of the last few days can still be released above approximately 2500 m. Mostly the avalanches are medium-sized but can be released also by a single winter sport participant.
Gradual increase in danger of wet avalanches as a consequence of warming during the day. Avalanches are possible as the day progresses, but they can be large in isolated cases. In the event of solar radiation this applies in particular on rocky slopes.
Backcountry tours, off-piste skiing and ascents to alpine cabins should be started early and concluded timely.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In some regions 20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen. In particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions there is still a very large amount of snow.
The surface of the snowpack will freeze to form a strong crust and will soften during the day. The spring-like weather conditions will give rise to rapid settling of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be very mild.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Early morning: Slab avalanches are possible adjacent to ridgelines. In particular, however, as the day progresses small and medium-sized moist snow slides and avalanches are to be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind slabs of the last few days can still be released above approximately 2500 m. Mostly the avalanches are medium-sized but can be released also by a single winter sport participant.
Gradual increase in danger of wet avalanches as a consequence of warming during the day. Avalanches are possible as the day progresses, but they can be large in isolated cases. In the event of solar radiation this applies in particular on rocky slopes.
Backcountry tours, off-piste skiing and ascents to alpine cabins should be started early and concluded timely.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In some regions 20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen. In particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions there is still a very large amount of snow.
The surface of the snowpack will freeze to form a strong crust and will soften during the day. The spring-like weather conditions will give rise to rapid settling of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be very mild.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wet snow represents the main danger. Backcountry tours and ascents to alpine cabins should be started and concluded early.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The weather will be very warm. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise from early morning to rapid softening of the snowpack over a wide area.
From the middle of the day the likelihood of moist and wet avalanches being released will increase significantly. Apart from the danger of being buried, restraint should be exercised in particular in view of the danger of avalanches sweeping people along and giving rise to falls.
In starting zones where no previous releases have taken place and at high altitude wet avalanches are possible as the day progresses. These can in isolated cases be released in near-ground layers and reach quite a large size.

On Wednesday the wind was moderate to strong in particular along the border with Switzerland and along the border with France. As a consequence of wind from northeasterly directions, mostly small wind slabs formed. They are clearly recognisable to the trained eye. The fresh wind slabs can in isolated cases be released by a single winter sport participant. These avalanche prone locations are to be found especially on very steep slopes above approximately 2700 m and adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
As a consequence of highly fluctuating temperatures the snowpack settled during the last few days.
Early morning: In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface. The surface of the snowpack will only just freeze and will soften earlier than the day before, in particular at low altitude.
During the day: Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise to rapid moistening of the snowpack below approximately 3800 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be exceptionally warm. These meteorological conditions will prevent a change towards better conditions in the early morning. The danger of moist and wet avalanches will already exist in the early morning.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wet snow represents the main danger. Backcountry tours and ascents to alpine cabins should be started and concluded early.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The weather will be very warm. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise from early morning to rapid softening of the snowpack over a wide area.
From the middle of the day the likelihood of moist and wet avalanches being released will increase significantly. Apart from the danger of being buried, restraint should be exercised in particular in view of the danger of avalanches sweeping people along and giving rise to falls.
In starting zones where no previous releases have taken place and at high altitude wet avalanches are possible as the day progresses. These can in isolated cases be released in near-ground layers and reach quite a large size.

On Wednesday the wind was moderate to strong in particular along the border with Switzerland and along the border with France. As a consequence of wind from northeasterly directions, mostly small wind slabs formed. They are clearly recognisable to the trained eye. The fresh wind slabs can in isolated cases be released by a single winter sport participant. These avalanche prone locations are to be found especially on very steep slopes above approximately 2700 m and adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
As a consequence of highly fluctuating temperatures the snowpack settled during the last few days.
Early morning: In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface. The surface of the snowpack will only just freeze and will soften earlier than the day before, in particular at low altitude.
During the day: Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise to rapid moistening of the snowpack below approximately 3800 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be exceptionally warm. These meteorological conditions will prevent a change towards better conditions in the early morning. The danger of moist and wet avalanches will already exist in the early morning.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase as the day progresses. Backcountry tours should be started and concluded early. In many places there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface. In the event of a clear night this applies in particular in the early morning.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of warming during the day and the solar radiation, the likelihood of moist and wet avalanches being released will increase in all aspects. The avalanche prone locations are to be found at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. Gliding avalanches can also occur, in particular on steep grassy slopes.
The wind slabs remain for the foreseeable future prone to triggering, especially adjacent to ridgelines. In all regions medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large avalanches are possible.
Avalanches can be released, mostly by large loads.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The weather conditions gave rise to thorough wetting of the snowpack over a wide area.
Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be quite good. The surface of the snowpack will freeze to form a strong crust and will soften during the day.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As a consequence of new snow and wind, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed in high Alpine regions. As a consequence of warming during the day and the solar radiation, the likelihood of dry and moist avalanches being released will increase gradually in particular on very steep sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The new snow and wind slabs can be released in some cases at intermediate and high altitudes.
In isolated cases the avalanches are medium-sized but can be released also by a single winter sport participant. In the event of solar radiation this applies in particular on very steep slopes.
As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation moist snow slides and avalanches are possible as the day progresses. Small and medium-sized natural avalanches are possible in particular on rocky sunny slopes.
Backcountry tours, off-piste skiing and ascents to alpine cabins should be started early and concluded timely.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
20 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last three days above approximately 2000 m. Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be quite good over a wide area. The spring-like weather conditions will give rise to increasing settling of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes. Above approximately 2000 m there is still a very large amount of snow.
In the last few days numerous small and medium-sized avalanches were observed.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Slight increase in danger of moist and wet avalanches as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As a consequence of new snow and wind, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed in high Alpine regions. As a consequence of warming during the day and the solar radiation, the likelihood of dry and moist avalanches being released will increase gradually in particular on very steep sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The new snow and wind slabs can be released in some cases at intermediate and high altitudes.
In isolated cases the avalanches are medium-sized but can be released also by a single winter sport participant. In the event of solar radiation this applies in particular on very steep slopes.
As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation moist snow slides and avalanches are possible as the day progresses. Small and medium-sized natural avalanches are possible in particular on rocky sunny slopes.
Backcountry tours, off-piste skiing and ascents to alpine cabins should be started early and concluded timely.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
20 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last three days above approximately 2000 m. Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be quite good over a wide area. The spring-like weather conditions will give rise to increasing settling of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes. Above approximately 2000 m there is still a very large amount of snow.
In the last few days numerous small and medium-sized avalanches were observed.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Slight increase in danger of moist and wet avalanches as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Weakly bonded old snow and wet snow require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation small to medium-sized moist and wet avalanches are possible above approximately 1700 m. In particular on shady slopes the avalanches can penetrate even deep layers. Weakly bonded old snow and wet snow require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack will be generally moist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation numerous medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large wet avalanches are possible as the day progresses.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Moist and wet avalanches and gliding avalanches and wet snow slides are to be expected in particular during the day.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The weather will be very warm. The danger of wet avalanches will increase during the day.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of warming and solar radiation, the activity of wet avalanches will gradually increase. On steep grassy slopes mostly small gliding avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Some snow fell on Wednesday in some localities. The surface of the snowpack will freeze very little and will already be soft in the early morning.

Below approximately 1800 m from a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Conditions are favorable concerning avalanche hazard.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The weather will be mostly sunny.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on shady slopes at intermediate and high altitudes. Mostly small avalanches are possible in particular on steep shady slopes. Avalanches can be released, mostly by large loads in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be good. The surface of the snowpack will freeze to form a strong crust and will soften during the day. On sunny slopes hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be mostly sunny. Over a wide area further warming.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The weather will be very warm. The danger of wet avalanches will increase during the day.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of warming and solar radiation, the activity of wet avalanches will gradually increase. On steep grassy slopes mostly small gliding avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Some snow fell on Wednesday in some localities. The surface of the snowpack will freeze very little and will already be soft in the early morning.

Below approximately 1800 m from a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Conditions are favorable concerning avalanche hazard.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wet snow slides and avalanches are possible in isolated cases. Mostly these are small.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Above approximately 2000 m: In gullies and bowls mostly small wet snow slides and avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Below approximately 1900 m hardly any snow is lying. The old snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations. The older wind slabs are to be found especially in gullies and bowls and at high altitudes. The snowpack will be generally moist.
